name: steel production, converter, low-alloyed | steel, low-alloyed | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/778/documentation

"Background:;This activity represents the production of primary low-alloyed steel in a basic oxygen furnace (BOF), a discontinuous process involving the following steps: 1) pretreatment of hot metal (pig iron) from the blast furnace (desulphurisation, deslagging, etc.); 2) mixing of charge (including alloying additions), weighing, transfer and reladling ; 3) oxidation in the BOF (decarburisation and oxidation of impurities); 4) secondary metallurgical treatment in a ladle furnace; and 5) casting (continuous and/or ingot).;;Modelling approach:;Data on were mostly taken from the IPPC Best Available Technology report from the European Commission (Remus et al., 2013); note that where only data ranges were provided, the geometric mean of reported values was used here. The proportion of each by-product that is recycled internally (i.e. returned as an input to the process after it has been produced) is based on measured data from plants worldwide reported by worldsteel (2010): slag (including desulphurisation slag, BOF slag, slag from secondary metallurgy and slag from continuous casting), 14%; spittings, 100%; dust and sludge, 22%; and mill scale, 89%.;;References:;Remus, R., Aguado-Monsonet, M. A., Roudier, S. & Samcho, L. D. (2013). JRC reference report - Best available techniques (BAT) reference document for iron and steel production. Joint Research Centre - European Commission, Luxemboug.;Worldsteel (2010). Steel industry by-products. World Steel Association: Brussels, Belgium."

At the gate of the steelmaking plant with the arrival of the hot metal (pig iron).

At the gate of the steelmaking plant with the cast steel ready for transport to manufacturers and fabricators.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/241:Manufacture of basic iron and steel/2410:Manufacture of basic iron and steel

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are mostly compiled from reports published between 2005 and 2010 but are considered representative of modern operations.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data are taken from basic oxygen furnace plants across Europe and are considered representative of the average situation globally.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Represents average European technology; LD converter and secondary metallurgy
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset is extrapolated from data collected from European sites; the uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Data were taken from direct measurements at blast furnace plants across Europe.

Note that there may be mass imbalances in the dataset. This is because the values represent the average situation in steelmaking  many different plants and have not been augmented or adjusted. Similarily, these values represent the situation post-ventilation/off-gas management, i.e. it is not the mass of carbon, for instance, that is produced that is reported but the amount that is actually, on average, emitted to the environment considering an average mix of steelmaking, technologies, off-gas management approaches, and internal recovery (recycling) or utilisation rates at integrated steelmakers in Europe. 

It should also be noted that data on radionucleid emissions to air, e.g. of Pollonium 210 and Lead 210, were not available and have therefore not been inventoried here.

Calculated as weighted average of values obtained from the literature, with national crude steel production through the basic oxygen furnace route in 2017 used as a weighting factor. exchanges.description:
Exchange added due to inclusion in Indian dataset. The amount was calculated based on the relative production volume of the Indian dataset against the global dataset.
Sponge iron is a good substitute for scrap which is required by the electric arc furnaces and induction furnaces or mini-steel plants in the country. The availability of indigenous metal scrap is scarce, and therefore, to meet the domestic demand, scrap is usually imported.
Sponge iron is a viable alternative for scrap and is produced by direct reduction of high-grade iron ore or pellets to metallic iron ore in solid state by using coal or natural gas as reductant. It is also known as Direct Reduced Iron (DRI) or Hot Briquetted Iron (HBI).

exchanges.description:
Calculated as weighted average of values obtained from the literature, with national crude steel production through the basic oxygen furnace route in 2017 used as a weighting factor. References:

Burchart-Korol, D., 2013. Life cycle assessment of steel production in Poland: a case study. Journal of Cleaner Production 54, 235-243. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2013.04.031
He, K., Wang, L., 2017. A review of energy use and energy-efficient technologies for the iron and steel industry. Renewable and Sustainable Energy Reviews 70, 1022-1039. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rser.2016.12.007
Ma, X., Ye, L., Qi, C., Yang, D., Shen, X., Hong, J., 2018. Life cycle assessment and water footprint evaluation of crude steel production: A case study in China. Journal of Environmental Management 224, 10-18. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jenvman.2018.07.027
Remus R., Aguado-Monsonet M., Roudier S., Sancho L., 2013. Best Available Techniques (BAT) Reference Document for Iron and Steel Production. Industrial Emissions Directive 2010/75/EU (Integrated Pollution Prevention and Control). JRC Reference report, JRC 69967

exchanges.description: geometric mean of Remus et al. (2013) data range.  Adjusted with RMS to balance Fe-Content.Note that the ratio of pig iron to iron scrap inputs was based on average data from European steelmakers. The values were then adjusted to ensure Fe balance. This ratio is, however, highly variable among regions, globally, and the value used may not be representative of a) the average global situation or b) the situation in other regions. We advise caution when appliying these data elsewhere.

exchanges.description:
Calculated as weighted average of values obtained from the literature, with national crude steel production through the basic oxygen furnace route in 2017 used as a weighting factor. Literature sources used:  Bieda, 2012; Burchart-Korol, 2013; He and Wang, 2017; Ma et al., 2018; Remus et al., 2013; Renzulli et al., 2016; Soni, 2018; Worrell et al., 2009

References: 
Bieda, B., 2012. Life cycle inventory processes of the ArcelorMittal Poland (AMP) S.A. in Kraków, Poland-basic oxygen furnace steel production. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment 17, 463-470. https://doi.org/10.1007/s11367-011-0370-y
Burchart-Korol, D., 2013. Life cycle assessment of steel production in Poland: a case study. Journal of Cleaner Production 54, 235-243. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2013.04.031
He, K., Wang, L., 2017. A review of energy use and energy-efficient technologies for the iron and steel industry. Renewable and Sustainable Energy Reviews 70, 1022-1039. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rser.2016.12.007
Ma, X., Ye, L., Qi, C., Yang, D., Shen, X., Hong, J., 2018. Life cycle assessment and water footprint evaluation of crude steel production: A case study in China. Journal of Environmental Management 224, 10-18. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jenvman.2018.07.027
Remus R., Aguado-Monsonet M., Roudier S., Sancho L., 2013. Best Available Techniques (BAT) Reference Document for Iron and Steel Production. Industrial Emissions Directive 2010/75/EU (Integrated Pollution Prevention and Control). JRC Reference report, JRC 69967
Renzulli, P., Notarnicola, B., Tassielli, G., Arcese, G., di Capua, R., 2016. Life Cycle Assessment of Steel Produced in an Italian Integrated Steel Mill. Sustainability 8, 719. https://doi.org/10.3390/su8080719
Soni, H., 2018. Iron ore, iron and steel production, India. SRI project report 
Worrell, E., Van Gent, Blinde, P., Maarten, N. Blomen, E., Masanet, E., 2009. Energy Efficiency Improvement and Cost Saving Opportunities for the U.S. Iron and Steel Industry An ENERGY STAR(R) Guide for Energy and Plant Managers.

exchanges.description:
Calculated as weighted average of values obtained from the literature, with national crude steel production through the basic oxygen furnace route in 2017 used as a weighting factor. Literature sources used:  Bieda, 2012; Burchart-Korol, 2013; He and Wang, 2017; Ma et al., 2018; Remus et al., 2013; Renzulli et al., 2016; Soni, 2018; Worrell et al., 2009

References: 
Bieda, B., 2012. Life cycle inventory processes of the ArcelorMittal Poland (AMP) S.A. in Kraków, Poland-basic oxygen furnace steel production. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment 17, 463-470. https://doi.org/10.1007/s11367-011-0370-y
Burchart-Korol, D., 2013. Life cycle assessment of steel production in Poland: a case study. Journal of Cleaner Production 54, 235-243. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2013.04.031
He, K., Wang, L., 2017. A review of energy use and energy-efficient technologies for the iron and steel industry. Renewable and Sustainable Energy Reviews 70, 1022-1039. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rser.2016.12.007
Ma, X., Ye, L., Qi, C., Yang, D., Shen, X., Hong, J., 2018. Life cycle assessment and water footprint evaluation of crude steel production: A case study in China. Journal of Environmental Management 224, 10-18. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jenvman.2018.07.027
Remus R., Aguado-Monsonet M., Roudier S., Sancho L., 2013. Best Available Techniques (BAT) Reference Document for Iron and Steel Production. Industrial Emissions Directive 2010/75/EU (Integrated Pollution Prevention and Control). JRC Reference report, JRC 69967
Renzulli, P., Notarnicola, B., Tassielli, G., Arcese, G., di Capua, R., 2016. Life Cycle Assessment of Steel Produced in an Italian Integrated Steel Mill. Sustainability 8, 719. https://doi.org/10.3390/su8080719
Soni, H., 2018. Iron ore, iron and steel production, India. SRI project report 
Worrell, E., Van Gent, Blinde, P., Maarten, N. Blomen, E., Masanet, E., 2009. Energy Efficiency Improvement and Cost Saving Opportunities for the U.S. Iron and Steel Industry An ENERGY STAR(R) Guide for Energy and Plant Managers.
